unnormalised: So, you're thinking of taking a loan, huh? Welcome to the club! It's like joining a gym – everyone *thinks* they'll get buff, but most end up just paying a monthly fee and feeling guilty. In the financial fitness world, that monthly fee is called EMI, and the guilt? Well, that’s knowing you’re paying 9.5% interest on that shiny new scooty you just *had* to have. Remember, Bajaj Finance isn't your chacha; they expect their Rs. 5000 on the 5th of every month, sharpish!
normalised: So, you're thinking of taking a loan, huh? Welcome to the club! It's like joining a gym – everyone *thinks* they'll get buff, but most end up just paying a monthly fee and feeling guilty. In the financial fitness world, that monthly fee is called E-M-I, and the guilt? Well, that’s knowing you’re paying nine point five percent interest on that shiny new scooty you just *had* to have. Remember, Bajaj Finance isn't your chacha; they expect their rupee five thousand on the fifth of every month, sharpish!

unnormalised: Seriously though, loans are a necessary evil, like that extra plate of biryani at a wedding. Tempting, delicious, but you'll regret it later. Credit cards are even worse – those little plastic devils whispering sweet nothings of 0% interest schemes. Just remember, that 0% turns into a whopping 3.5% per month if you miss the due date. My friend, Rajat, learned that the hard way, and now he’s eating Maggi for dinner every night for the next 6 months to pay off his Rs. 25000 debt. Ouch!

unnormalised: Now, let's talk CIBIL score. Think of it as your financial report card. A good score (750+) means lenders will throw money at you like it's a Bollywood rain scene. A bad score? Well, let's just say you'll be begging your uncle for a personal loan at an even more embarrassing interest rate. I saw one chap's CIBIL score; it was 400 something. Looked like he'd been financing everything, and I mean *everything*.

Well, let's just say you'll be begging your uncle for a personal loan at an even more embarrassing interest rate. I saw one chap's C-I-B-I-L score; it was four hundred something. Looked like he'd been financing everything, and I mean *everything*.

unnormalised: But fear not, intrepid borrower! With a little planning and a healthy dose of caution, you can navigate the loan landscape without ending up bankrupt and selling your kidney on OLX. Do your research, compare interest rates from HDFC, ICICI, and even that shady loan app your cousin recommended. Maybe even read the fine print (gasp!), which is usually written in font size -2. And remember, just because you *can* borrow Rs. 1 lakh doesn't mean you *should*.

unnormalised: Ultimately, taking a loan is like marriage – a big commitment that can either make you or break you. Choose wisely, don't overextend yourself, and always remember that chai and paratha are cheaper than a luxury car. Unless, of course, you're borrowing to start a chai-paratha stall. Then, my friend, you're a genius! Just don't forget the GST.
